Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Since surgery with the hand is established in our region and since it has been for a long time known everywhere within us alone (if you understand this Latin phrase as referring to knowledge or practice that was once common but now only exists in certain texts): until perhaps science of his work perishes, there will be an end sought; those who searched after him are left without other remains than the skimpy descriptions found here and among ancient books whose hands have worn away. Thus having read these instructions within a book on cauterization equipment and other instruments related to operation: once again it is necessary that I complete this work in accordance with intention (meaning intended use), expression (specific terms or descriptions), abbreviation (shortened forms of words) as stated, and also according to the additional information provided within declarations.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	Because it is not found a good surgeon who possesses his work with hands in this time of ours: for the art of medicine is long and requires an author to practice beforehand (indicating knowledge) science of Anatomy, as narrated by Galenus, until he understands how members are joined together or separated from one another; also their shapes, forms, joint connections between them in union with others: along with the cognition that each bone has regarding its own skeleton (which includes all types of bones and teeth), arrangement within themselves on which they rest upon each other. Therefore he must understand as well how blood arises from veins flowing into vessels to leave their exit points, in addition also what quietens heartbeat or causes pain at a certain location with the help of hot springs: not forgetting that it is necessary for him firstly know about organs and bodily exits; he must understand all this well beforehand if one wants success.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And because Hippocrates said that a name with many words and little work is especially suited to the art of surgery.

Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	For who is not skilled in anatomy and knows what we have told about it so that he will no longer fall into error because men are destroyed by them: I myself saw many of these people make up their minds without this science or knowledge from which they proceed, having neither the skill nor experimentation.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	What happened was that I saw a foolish surgeon who infected his patient with scrofulous swellings and made some cuts into the woman' startling blood vessels: as a result, her blood flowed until she died in the hands of this maniac.

And I saw another doctor who had accepted the fee from some dukes' land in exchange for medical services; and an ebony-colored eunuch fell at his feet near him, having a fracture just above the heel: which was done unintentionally by himself. And I saw another doctor who punctured the malignant swelling and an open sore appeared on the next day; which until his wickedness was revealed to his lordship, it flourished beautifully.

That is so because when there's cancer pure from a melancholic humor in the body at that time, it shouldn't be allowed to perish within him with iron entirely; unless he has an organ that can tolerate everything and allows its entire removal.

Take then with care and protection the measure of my words; aid our weakened bodies easily and securely (with healing), keep improving your way pleasing to God that leads us safely toward health and honorable life after death: relinquish grievous illnesses hard to cure, remove heavy souls burdened by such troubles from me. Let them not fear those things which scare you so as not to cause hesitation in their faith on your sake and for your good (convenience).

¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	On the use of cautery in wound treatment and how it relates to the patient's condition, time sensitivity, and choice between using iron or gold as a medium for this practice.
Caput I.	1. De laceratione traiectum
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	1. On the topic of lacerations and their treatment through cautery. It's essential to recount not only how Albucasis applied this technique but also his views on its risks, specifically regarding potential necrosis or tissue damage (Iuuementum et Nocumentum Cauterii). Additionally, it should be clear under what conditions he considered cautery appropriate and the timing of its application. Furthermore, Albucasis outlined scenarios where a choice had to be made between using
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	1. On the topic of lacerations and their treatment through cautery: Albucasis believed that discussions on the quality of surgical instruments like iron tongs used for cauterization are excessively verbose but subtle in knowledge, reflecting a deeply scientific understanding while remaining secretive or occult to others.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	1. Even though Albucasis had spoken on this subject among many wise individuals, they disagreed with him and I find that the discussions are insufficient for me due to my fear of overextension in conversation about these surgical instruments and techniques used by cauterization.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	1. I argue that cauterization provides a universal benefit to all kinds of wounds without considering the material composition: except for two types - one being heat-related injuries absent external application (calida) and another dry injury also independent of direct stimuli or materials involved (sicca). These exceptions showcase Albucasis' understanding that cauterization, while beneficial in most cases, requires specific considerations when dealing with unique wound types.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	1. In the case of other injuries where heat and dryness are present together but also involve material (like foreign bodies or debris), differing opinions arose among Albuc
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	1. Some indeed said that cautery is suitable for those injuries as well. This implies a broader acceptance of the use of heat and iron or other conductive materials to manage wounds beyond just lacerations, suggesting alternative applications may have been recognized by
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	1. Others argued the opposite view that cautery is not suitable for such ailments as well; specifically citing heat and dryness (caliditate ac siccitate). Since fire inherently represents heat (ignis est caliditas), it would be inappropriate to use something hot or even cold, which can also cause further harm when the injury is already from warmth or arid conditions. This position indicates a nuanced understanding of wound treatment that considers not just external temperatures but their effects on healing processes and potential for additional damage before cauterization might be considered at all by Albucasis or his contemporaries.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	And he who speaks against him said that by means of Cauterium it is performed incision or burning for every hot and dry illness that occurs within the human body; because when you compare a living man's body with its moisture, as if likened to fire, then inevitably you find his body cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	And indeed I say by his words: because at some point now it has left me through experiment.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	However it should not come to pass unless he has already been tried and exercised in the chapter of Cauterii operation itself; having known for a long time the diversity of human complexions, as well as the disposition towards diseases within themselves and their causes and accidents, along with the spaces they occupy temporally.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	However there is no fear of these remaining persons for the use [of Cauterium]: especially with regard to diseases that are cold and moist.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	Now all the physicians have nourished themselves with this [discourse on cauterization]: and they did not disagree therein.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And he knows that his son understands [the secret of curing through Cauterium with fire and its virtue over burning medicines]: for it is simple, whose action does not reach the body unless cauterized: nor does a member join in union with another except to nerve parasitic growth.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	The action of medicine with burning has come to this [that it extends from the body's members]: and perhaps even happens within the member itself; making difficult healing possible, or causing death.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	Fire because of its subtlety and goodness does not do that [cauterize] unless it is in excess.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	Now indeed it becomes clear to us through the experience of trial and study with art [surgery], as well as being stationed over urging things along in reality; hencefors, because of this he has been released from that long narrative.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if it were not so that this book of mine is closed to you, we would reveal to your secretly hidden mysteries in fire and the nature of such operations as they expel diseases through language philosophically demonstrated with intent to cure minds afflicted by ailments.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And the son knows that they disagree at the time when it was fitting to do a hot iron and choose better timing with words.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	And I say that the hot iron was meant for all time: therefore, because a harmful effect occurs due to being engulfed by water, it is drawn into injury along with the treatment itself.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	Particularly if the hot iron is due to acute pain from indispenerable needs such as wounds that do not endure delay: henceforth it happens because of fear born out of this, which concerns a greater harm than any minor injury caused by tardiness in time.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And it will not fall to the mind of such a son who does not fear unless they are influenced by foolish or inept physicians: for these individuals believe that diseases treated with hot iron do not return forever; and so they endorse this misconception, which is incorrect because there would be no use of fire except within medicine's practice. Specifically to treat conditions like complexion alterations and loss of moisture due to causes such as fever or chills that result in pain: for these individuals wrongly conclude a cure by themselves without the aid of medical treatment which requires this hot application, because there would be no need for fire unless it served within medicine.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	Nevertheless, the hot iron is superfluous to medicine through excessive or unjustified surgery and operation efforts: as well as arrogance towards one's own domain; it is possible that healing will return a patient for some time period according to their condition regarding complexion and location of illness, provided they are not suffering from an ailment requiring the administration of hot iron. This happens because preparation occurs within them: which succeeds in returning directly back into themselves through food intake and similar provisions (not if there is disease), as part of its inherent curative action that does not necessitate external fire application, since it returns without this need for medicinal practices outside the body.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	The delicate pain under the excessively moist and swollen limb is due to humidity, like that of dental burning therapy, which makes it possible for him not to return with pain there.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But this hurts little.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	But really that speech is just talking nonsense again: because they say it's about the last medicine in surgery (cutorium), which does not lead to this thing intended therein by themselves, nor with any other aftercare associated therapy as well; since those who use such believe it provides a cure when it has been given no curative treatment and nothing else is done afterwards.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	But on the contrary of this opinion is true, and intent in that medicine which they claim as last surgery: it's not so unless when we administered to any patient with disease for some curative means (medical methods), then gave those medical treatments; afterward apply our own cauterism proper methodology therapy. After applying this procedure, the reason of saying that such medicine is last in surgery no longer exists: because as it was originally intended by them themselves and multistolidorum physicians - whom they think to be ignorant fools with many opinions about health matters- does not refer to those actual practices which we have administered beforehand, but instead follows misguided words of the unlearned.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	But the ancients said that caustic with gold is better than caustic with iron; and did not say this except because of equality in metal (gold's value), sublimity of substance, and also it does not make a place where pus may arise.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	But this is not absolutely true; for I have already tried that out and found it to be false: because itself does not make a cause without other things (without additional medical interventions) on some bodies only, but rather exacerbates the condition by introducing heat where dryness should suffice.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And indeed that is a good and better caustic than iron, as they said: because it does not burn like fire but rather cools the area with less discomfort to patient's flesh while still promoting healing of wounds through its cauterizing effect
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	However, when you take an iron cauterium from fire into gold and do not declare it to be so before using it on the subject according to the amount of poison produced by its heat because of blackening with oil; and after proper treatment for coldness has been applied as well as placing a layer above this incision, when these treatments are complete, then melts in fire and is poured into layers.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Therefore, because the instrument falls from that into its employment; and since our cautery with iron is more nearly to nature in this respect: it approaches nearer accordingly towards surgical operations.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	And I indeed have arranged this chapter on cautery according to the sections from head to foot, in order that one seeking it may find what is desired about such a matter herein mentioned.

¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	By way of performing Cauterization on the head throughout all pain of the head.
Caput III.	Chapter Three.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	Whenever throughout the entire head an enduring pain occurs: and this continues to afflict it with sickness, and resorts hitherto therein in desperation of relief by various methods such as fomentations, purgings, Cauterizations, oils for soothing, or emollients.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And especially if after performing Cauterization once as described in our narrative and no further benefits are derived from that one treatment only: then reflect upon this thought.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	For if the head of an afflicted patient has a strong natural constitution that is not weak or sick and experiences chilling sensations due to cold winds, then with Cauterization apply it no more under any circumstances than another form of treatment would be applied in this case.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Thereafter, apply Cauterization to the entire outer edge of his own head' extraducting no through any skin breach and extracting as much fat from bone as we have described in our account.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	And apply Cauterization to one place at the back of his own head; that spot which is called "wax" and it's a location where pressure is applied without breaking through the skin or removing bone: as described herein, anoint this with your oil but do not remove any bone.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	For the patient suffers due to this pain vehemently and it endures for various treatments of Cauterization applied throughout all ills affecting his head: as previously mentioned in our discussion.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I will say this is the Cautery in its own place: and it must be what kind of a cautery to burn the ears; more refined than that for burning the head underneath.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is how it looks like this one.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	On the way of cauterizing inside the head, both with heated medicine and iron.
Caput IIII.	Head IV.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When it happens that a pain occurs inside the head, hot as well as cold remedies are used; and when such pains extend to either eye sockets or temples they cease in turn with drugs meant for cleaningseating heads; I have also described elsewhere certain other treatments which should be administered according to my division of diseases. Thus, cauterization at that time is done by two ways: one way using acute hot combustion medicine or another like a heated iron instrument. Not all cases need this treatment in full; then it depends on the type and severity of pain whether such intervention will be necessary or not.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	And when using a hot burning cauterizing instrument with medicine as well it is like taking the tooth of an enemy and tearing off its horns; then you have him remove both ends from his head by cutting through two sides simultaneously. This metaphorically illustrates how aggressively one must act upon diseases within, using tools that apply similar severity in treatment as a warrior does against their foes.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur. Therefore I shall say this to put it right there under the skin until it disappears; afterwards tie over with string a moderate constriction on top of its swelling, and then release it for fifteen hours, after which remove both garlic cloves (ulnar) twice more. Following that, place cotton soaked in butyrum subcutaneously into the affected area until pus accumulation is achieved; subsequently care with ointment will restore health to this part as well. Caput VII.	Head Seven.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	Surgery that uses caustic is only applicable to those who suffer from inflammation as we have discussed before regarding the division of diseases.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And about caustic treatment for that species which occurs from a fistula and paralysis of the nerves.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When curing this species of surgery with hemorrhoids and scrofula, your cure does not suffice; then it is necessary that you also causticize the weak three times using a different tool each time: one near the root of the ear, another beneath its little horn (metaphorically referring to lesser parts), and thirdly at the junction between two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And place your caustic opposite, or antithesis of weakness as you have it ready for treatment against these afflictions.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	Since salvections do not occur unless on the part that appears healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of caustic treatment is such that it cauterizes with its own instrument, a small one on top of the ear above the crown of the head (nearest to the forehead), and another in the tonsil: whose length should correspond to the span of the thumb.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And lay down your hand with the instrument until it has consumed halfway through skin thickness.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	And this is the form of Cauterium and it belongs to a category similar to lancets whose shape precedes; although its sharpness need not be subtler than those eyes: and therefore, let there also be an excess in size for that instrument too on account of thickened grossed areas.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Thereafter care for wounds until they heal.

¶ De incisione Alguardenic, et carne nata in oculo.	Regarding Albucasis' incision on a fetus stillborn within the eye:
Caput XVII.	Chapter VII.
Nascitur quandoque in quibusdam oculis hominum caro rubea composita, uel superposita, donec cooperit pupillam, aut appropinquat, aut stringit super palpebras, et fortasse conuertit palpebras ad exteriora: et assimilatur rosae balaustinae. Whenever you complete the incision and remove all foreign bodies without any damage, then open (the eye) by contraction with an oil or distillation of red lead from medicine that is corrosive; place a poultice of white radish over it covered with alumina to protect against sunburn.
Quod si remanet ex alguardenici aliquid, et dominatur tibi sanguis calidus, et times apostema calidum: tunc dimitte oculum, et cura ipsum cum eo quod sedat apostema. ¶ De cura Carnis natae in naso.	The treatment for a nose wound.

Sit in eo quiddam grossitudinis paulatim, ut stringatur, uel teneatur cum eo os, et non fugiat et uadat, donec egrediatur os: et restaura locum cum medicinis conuenientibus ad illud.	Sit in that matter gradually and firmly as it is grasped with this tooth' extrusion until the tooth has retreated out of its socket, and then restore the place using appropriate medicine: which will be suitable for such an event.
Si autem in osse est putredo parua, tunc rade ipsum a putredine sua, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	If there is only partial decay within the bone, then immediately remove what remains of it and care for that until healed: which will be taken as necessary action at such an event.

Since it was born after another tooth has come out and cannot be attached or its cusp removed without risk of breaking the remaining: remove this root thoroughly: and if there are any remnants affixed with a different tooth, then place them into this instrument, which is thus shaped.

If there is any part of the tooth that breaks and causes damage to the tongue: it must be removed as well along with its sharp edge until only a smooth surface remains which has been flattened in this way so as not to harm or impair speech, nor blemish appearance.
¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	On the treatment of teeth and gold thread fillings.
Caput XXXIII.	De dentibus et aurum quod sublimatum sese
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	Whenever the anterior teeth suffer from concussion and pain due to percussion, it happens for reasons of this kind that they cannot be securely grasped with forceps as not to fall out; instead you treat them using hemostatic medications without any surgical intervention. The skill here is in their being gripped firmly between gold wires: because silver corrodes quickly, and turns into rust after some days but gold does not change its nature.
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	And let there be a thread or suture made delicate and strong according to its weight that will hold between teeth.
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	And the method of suturing is that you receive a thread and insert its double into two healthy teeth: then pull with both ends of the thread (or one or more), so as to move each end between teeth, until you reach the safe side of another tooth while holding on the thread.
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	Thereafter continue texturing until you reached the part wherein thou hast placed it; and then with a thread twisted by thy delicate skill and wisdom hold fast therewith not without excess: let your suturing of the thread be among the roots of teeth, so as that they shall not come off.
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	Thereafter cut the surplus ends of threads overhangs and aggregate them together with their respective parts; then fold them back upon themselves in a way that they form no harm, not leaving any hanging thread between teeth: thus preventing damage to the tongue while remaining so until removed.
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	If any thread breaks or gets outgrown: then tie it back with a new one in the same manner as before until all threads are held firmly by that time together.
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	This is how the tooth ought be set and shaped; as for setting up two teeth together in their right places: of four healthy ones whereof two are moved around by them (as we see), so that they form a complete dental arch, like ours do. This I have called "the Form of Tooth" among sur
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	And whenever it needs to be repaired so that one or two teeth return from their respective places in the gap left by urchins after shells have been removed and returned as we narrate: remaining there until something else is done unless an artisan, wise, skilled, and knowledgeable can restore them.
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	And when some tooth is fitly fashioned from bones or ivory: it is made in the likeness of a tooth and set into its place wherein density is secured with threading as we have described; remaining there for an extended period until something else takes effect.
¶ De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et prohibet loquelam.	On deciding to make an incision under the tongue, he strictly forbids it.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter 34.
Quandoque ligamentum hoc quod accidit sub lingua, est aut naturale, cum quo nascitur homo, aut accidentale, a uulnere quod iam consolidatum est.	Whenever an incision is made under the tongue (whether it be natural with which man is born or due to some injury that has now become established),...
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi in capite eius in sinu tuo, et eleua linguam eius: deinde incide illud ligamentum neruosum per latitudinem, donec soluatur lingua a retentione sua.	And the operation is to open his mouth wide so that your infirmity of the head will be inside his mouth and he will pull out its tongue (if applicable), then proceeds with an incision through this nerve root underneath until he can remove her [the patient]'s tongue by detaching it from around.
Quod si in eo fuerit quiddam duriciei et nodationis, et fuerit illud ex consolidatione uulneris: tunc proiice in illud uncinum, et finde illud per latitudinem, donec incidas ligamentum, et soluatur nodatio.	But if it were something as hard and knotted (or due to some injury that had become established), then he takes out a hook from the uncinate process of his hyoid bone or mandible ('throat' in Latin) by extending its side, until he finds this root through which 'it passes,' makes an incision along it downwards till reaching ligamentum (which is where we are), and then removes that nodule.
Et caue, ne sit fissura in profundo carnis, et incidas arteriam illic, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And if it should break through the deep tissue of his chest, we make an incision there and pierce that blood vessel; then flows out.

Deinde pone sub lingua licinium ex lino, quod teneat infirmus in omni nocte: ut non consolidetur secundo.	Then he places a linen bandage under the tongue (which contains his illness for all night) so that it will not harden by second.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc pone super locum zegi tritum.	But if blood flows out, then he places a lead seal over the spot where it has bled to stop further bleeding.
Si uero uincit te sanguis, tunc cauteriza locum cum cauterio lentiginoso, quod conuenit ad illud: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	But if you fight with blood flowing out of your body (i.s., it is bleeding), then he applies a light-scorched lead to the place where it has bled; thereafter takes care for his own cautery, until that wound gets well.

¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	On opening blisters, and their sections, and general care.
Caput XL.	Chapter Forty.
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	Blisters come in many species and numerous varieties as to which we have here a remembrance; this book contains but one of each kind, with the exception that it records two for their perforation or tear: these are divided into dual ways of being torn or pierced.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	One is an internal blister belonging to itself and that which it encompasses by moisture.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	And the second mode is due to location whereby accident occurs from within the body.
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	Since an internal blister is located at the head and thus it differs from a blow struck on the skin surface; another type of injury due to location occurs within the flesh, which contrasts with the tearing that takes place in joint tissue: each one has its own verdict based upon operation.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	And from among blisters those which do not need to be pierced unless after they have been cleaned; and these are the ones that must be pierced when raw, but never mature according to their accompanying supplement: amongst them there is one for each purpose.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	As blisters which belong close together with joint tissue injuries..
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	Since when an internal blister occurs near a joint and becomes longer until it rots therein; perhaps its decay may even corrupt the tendons or ligaments of that particular joint, therefore serving as a cause for greater contraction: so indeed this is due to more serious constriction.
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	It is an abscess near the main joint: because if you delay puncturing it until it heals, whether through this or by that limb principal.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	It is about the navel: so puncture it while immature; and it should not be done unless for a natural abscess near the navel, that does not perforate but becomes suppurated deep inside to extend towards the intestines thereby forming an internal fistula or leading outside which cannot heal.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	It is necessary to know the time of puncturing an abscess that has matured in accordance with complement; and it concerns itself with pain due to inflammation or feverishness, decrease of reddeness on the skin, pulsebeats, throbbing headaches related to such abcesses: etc.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	It is necessary to perform the same puncture on an abscess that has matured at its location; and with strong prominence: it should be done if there are abcesses in parts of hands and feet, as well as in places for lizards and chords (vessels or blood channels), nerves, arteries, everywhere equally to which is not retroflection.
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	And in those cases where they are reflected, let there be puncture according with that member. (It's not clear what "illis" refers to; it seems like a grammat0ical error or misinterpretation.)

G., and then scraped off completely by every part; moreover has a pair of lips made up out of skin, either alone or multiple small ones as some cases require for this cyst-like structure in exactly like how we described with head nodules - similar to apostates' heads – but gradually outside it.

If the pumice stone (Strophula) has been entirely used up: then it is necessary to join together two wounds with their own secretions and immediately after that, since no excessive foam remained on them just as they are now.

¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	About the incision in which one must cut into the epiglottis inside the throat due to an emergency situation involving airway obstruction caused by foreign objects: proceed carefully and promptly, with appropriate medical
Caput XLIII.	Head Forty-Three.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	They praised the ancient cutting of this incision into the epiglottis and they have not seen anyone on our land who has done it: that is their written testimony.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	They have the wax tablet and they need to see a cut into the epiglottis: so that there will not be an injury through it: because all who are sick with these diseases (dyspnea or laryngitis) suffer from weakness in both body and spirit.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	In those who have suffered with hot food lodged in the mouth or throat, or even twice between two almonds when there is no obstruction of the canals (airways), it is necessary to make a cut into the epiglottis for preventing exclusion from life because of imminent death.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	Therefore, when we intend to perform it (the cut into the epiglottis), let us do so under three arcs of Epiglotis or four, a small incision made through its breadth at that place which is between two circles: and this must be done not in cartilage but where flesh is located from there are blood vessels nearby. This location was appropriate for making the cut because it contains meat (cartilaginous tissue) close to veins, so as not to cause a hemorrhage.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	If the physician is fearful (anxious or hesitant), then it is necessary to expand the incision in the throat with a lancet.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then they found it (the incision), until he reaches the trachea: if there is blood coming out of it or anything else seen in it must be drained with a toothpick.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then they drained the sifac (phlegm) which we described: and it is expressed by cutting into the trachea from that phlegm which emerges out of it when this has been disrupted so as to cause removal with words.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And they release one who is cut open at some point in time, that he may recover his health promptly and completely without any delay or hindrance whatsoin!
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When then is it that the hour appointed for treatment begins? Remove two weakened lips of skin and without chondrion.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Thereafter administers such medical treatments that give birth to a healthy child until it is safe.

¶ De curatione Vulnerum capitis sine fractura ossis.	On healing skull without bone cracks.
Caput LXXXIIII.	Chapter XXXIV.
Iam dixi in diuisione de curatione uulnerum quod conueniebat libro, et ego dicam hic curationem eorum cum manu, et cum medicinis secundum complementum.	Now I have said the treatment of wounds that suits books and will say here their healing by hand and with medicine according to its support..
Dico ergo, quod uulnera diuersificantur secundum illud quo fiunt uulnera, et secundum locum super quem cadit uulnus.	I say therefore that wounds are of many kinds according to where they fall and what causes them..
Res ergo quibus fiunt uulnera multotiens, sunt sicut iactus lapidis: aut incisio ensis, aut cultelli: aut percussio cum lancea, aut ligno, aut sagitta: et similibus illis ex rebus multis.	Therefore where they fall often the wounds are as when struck with a stone or cut by knife edge; and incisions like cutting open fishes' bellies for their guts to be removed, also percussing of them upon lancea, ligno, sagittae et similibus.
Vulnera autem quae fiunt secundum loca corporis sunt, sicut uulnus quod cadit super caput, aut collum, aut pectus, aut uentrem, aut epar: et similia ex eis membris.	Wounds which fall according to where the body falls are as a wound on head if it hits above crown of skull; also falling upon neck (collum) or breast-bone (pectus); shoulder, chest and abdomen: there with like members in case..
Et ego sum narrans curationes quorundam uulnerum, ut ponam eam ratiocinationem et regulam super reliqua uulnera.	And I am a teller of certain wound treatments putting forth this reasoning and rule for the remaining wounds..
Et ego incipiam a uulneribus capitis simplicibus: quoniam rememoratio compositorum ueniet in principio capituli tertii.	And I will begin with skull simple fractures, since the memory of writers begins at chapter III..
Dico ergo.	I say therefore: (translation not provided)
Quando accidit in capite uulnus simplex, et non est fractura ossis: considera tunc, si est ex iactu lapidis, aut ei similibus, et iam fregit cutem tantum: et est uulnus magnum, et times super infirmum euentum apostematis calidi: tunc propera, et phlebotoma cephalicam statim: et non tardes illud: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius: si non fuerit prohibens aliquid a phlebotomia, praecipue si fuerit sanguis qui egreditur ex uulnere paucus.	When it happens that there is simple wound in the head without any bone cracks: consider at this time if from blow by stone or like things; and then he has wounded only skin, but a great one which immediately after falls victim to apostate swelling (a serious reaction); now make him cool with water as soon as possible. At that very instant apply cold phlebotomic medication on the head directly: according to amount of blood loss by injuring his wound; if it is not forbidden from aphetical punishment, particularly when there will be little blood which comes outwardly (from the injury). And draw off this bleeding with veins as much as needed for salubrity and health. If phlebotomy has been prohibited by any authority: especially if it is of small quantity coming from wounds..
Et sit phlebotomia ex contrario partis uulneratae.	And let there be a bloodletting from the opposite side of the wounded area.
Et caueat infirmus sibi a repletione, et uino, et cibis grossis.	Let him who is ill abstain from eating solid food after being satiated and drink wine thickly.
Si autem minutionem prohibet aliquid, tunc minoretur ex cibo, et non appropinquet carnibus, neque uinis.	If he does not allow any thing besides food in the meal at that time, let him have only a little of what is eaten from the dish and drink no wine closely or with meat; nor approach to it without proper restriction.
Et pone super uulnus si accidit ei apostema calidum, cotum infusum in oleo rosato solo, aut cum uino in quo est stipticitas.	And put vinegar on the hot wound if it occurs and drip cool water over its forehead or with wine which contains astringency; whichever is used as such when properly administered will suffice.   
Si autem securus fueris ab apostemate calido, tunc pone super uulnus, si est recens cum sanguine suo, et non mutauit ipsum aer, puluerem quem ego narrabo post paululum: et si iam mutauit ipsum aer, tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, donec sanetur.	If you were secure from the hot sore, then pour vinegar on it if there is still blood with it and do not let its air change; I will mention briefly afterwards a purple clay which has been used in this case by some afterward: but when even that aer had changed for them, they poured over such wounds certain greenish substances till healed.   
Si autem uulnus est magnum, aut est ex incisione ensis, et similium: et non aggregantur labia eius per puluillos, tunc aggrega ipsa cum sutura, secundum quod ego narrabo in uulneribus uentris de sutura eorum.	If there is a great wound or it was caused by the sword and similar; then when their lips were not joined with threads but only stitched upon, they themselves are bandaged together securely following what I describe in my writings on treating sutured injuries.   
Si autem uulnus iam detectum est ab osse, et pendet, et non est retentio eius, nisi in suspensorio paruo: tunc incide ipsum.	If there is a wound from the bone which hangs and does not become constricted unless it has been put into its supporting bandage of warm water; then pour that over such injuries till healed, as I have described to be done at this time by some.   
Deinde cura uulnus cum medicinis, et restaura in eo carnem duram loco cutis, et praecipe infirmo, ut alatur cibis in quibus est grossitudo, sicut sunt capita, et triticum coctum, donec sit ut puls: et eis similia.	Thereafter take care of the wound with medicines and restore it to its original place; skin over bone or cuts; also instruct such a patient how to eat those hard food items found in his own body, like heads and cooked grains until he feels strong enough: as I have described that treatment for them at this time.   
Quod si inuenis in cute putrefactionem, et non adhaeret ossi: tunc incide putrefactum totum, et proiice ipsum: deinde cura illud.	If you find the wound with a part of it decomposed and not attached to bone; then pour over that whole decomposition until healed completely as I have described by some at this time who took care for such injuries afterward, but afterwards also pay careful attention: they called their first course on which all infection was poured out "disinfected wound".   
Si autem in his uulneribus est arteria, aut uena ex qua fluit sanguis: et non abscinditur per medicinas, tunc inquire super arteriam.	If there is an artery within the wound or if it carries blood flow: and do not remove it through medicine at that time; rather investigate over the artery.
Si ergo inuenis eam non sectam, tunc seca eam cum Spatumili, aut liga eam.	If I find this has been incised: then dry it out with Bullion or bind it up.
Quod si necessitas prouocat quando non confert illud quod diximus, tunc cauteriza eam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If the need arises at a time when we have not provided what was just mentioned: then burn it out until blood stops flowing from it.
Si autem uulnera ista sunt parua, simplicia, tunc res eorum est facilis, leuis: ita ut puluerizes super ea hunc puluerem: quoniam consolidat ea antequam mutet ea aer.	If these wounds are shallow and clean, then the remedy for them is simple, lightening; thus that thing which has medicine on it will harden before changing air.
¶ Modus Pulueris incarnatiui.	The method of anointing a living person.   
Recipe olibani partem unam, et sanguinis draconis partes duas, et calcis non extinctae partes tres: teratur totum multum, et cribelletur: et impleatur ex eo uulnus, et constringatur constrictione bona, donec adhaereat super ipsum bene, et coaguletur cum sanguine.	Take one part of opossum and mix with two parts dragon's blood for the first; take three unburnt foot pieces as second; heat all well together: it will bubble up much, crumble fine by beating: then pour into a wound to fill in from its own juice until firmly attached on top of itself and squeezed with blood.
Deinde stringe ipsum desuper cum puluillis, et dimitte ipsum, neque soluas ipsum dum permanet, ita quod non apostemetur.	Thereafter press the poultice above to woollen cloth and remove gently; do not expect it stay attached while still inside for too long hence unattached part should be removed promptly afterward as well.
Nam non eradicatur ab eo medicina, donec sanatur.	Meanwhile medicine does not eliminate but gets healed until fully recovered.
Et quandoque facit illud calx sola, quando non sunt tibi in praesenti olibanum, et sanguis draconis etiam facit eandem operationem in multis ex uulneribus magnis, quando conuenit ut ponatur super ea et stringantur, et sunt uulnera recentia cum sanguine suo, quae non alterauit aer.	And when he makes this stone alone then not having at the moment opossum but dragon'deal blood also does make a similar operation in several large wounds whereby can be placed on it and bound tightly around it until they are injured recently with their own blood which has never been mixed before.
Quod si iam alterauit ea aer quadam alteratione, praecipue quando est in tempore aestatis, tunc non est in positione huius pulueris intentio: cura ergo ipsum cum eo quod diximus, ita ut ponas super ea quaedam unguenta digestiua: aut ponas super ea pultes ex farina hordei, factas cum aqua et melle, donec emittant pus.	If however that air has undergent a change and particularly when in summer time then the purpose of this poultice is no longer intended: therefore care for it with some other healing ointment as discussed previously or apply over it paste made from wheat flour, mixed together with water and honey until pus comes forth.
Deinde cura ea reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Thereafter care for the remaining part of healing as discussed: continue to do so till they are completely healthy again.   This completes all translations from a medieval Latin text
Si uero accidat cum uulnere fractura in osse, et est parua, tunc extrahe illud cum Gesti: et ego iam dicam curationem fracturarum capitis in eo quod futurum est.	If therefore when wound has a bone fracture and is incomplete then remove it from the outside with Albucasis as he does: I myself will henceforays on treating crumbled skulls just like that which was to come in future treatment according to him. SI Est percussio lanceae, aut cultelli: et uides eius profunditatem, tunc considera. Si ergo ex uulnere egreditur uentositas, quando anhelat ex eo infirmus, tunc scias, quia uulnus est mortale.	If then from wounds he who hastens outwardly emerges weak and pants for air, at that time you know because a wound is fatal.
Quod si non fuerit ei profunditas, et est recens cum sanguine suo: tunc non ponas in eo a prima hora puluerem, neque stringas ipsum, ut non retineatur sanguis in profunditate eius, et reuertatur ad cor, et interficiat infirmum: sed pone in ipso unguentum attractiuum, et solue ipsum in die bis.	But if not very deep and is bleeding freshly with his own blood, then you do not place a scalpel on him at first light nor bind the wound tight so that the blood does not remain deeply within it but returns to the heart and restores strength in two days: however, apply an attractive ointment to him, leaving him unbound for another day.
Si uero unguentum non est tibi praesens, tunc pone in orificio uulneris cotum uetustum, ut sugat illud quod egreditur de eo ex humiditatibus: et fac ut dormiat infirmus super uulnus, ut currat quod aggregatur in eo.	If indeed you do not have the ointment at hand then place a poultice of couched wound with some sour stuff on his ulcer so that it comes out from him through humidity: and make him lie upon this ulcer, thus allowing what enters to flow in.
Si uero iam praeterierint uulneri tres dies, aut plures, et non accidit infirmo spasmus, neque tremor cordis malus, neque strictura in anhelitu, et uides reliquas dispositiones eius bonas: tunc scias, quia uulnus est saluum. Thereafter I tried to secure it and removed a piece of bone after detecting the first one as before; moreover, finding that there was still decay with the bone - which had become evident in my observation while removing pieces from the initial detachment – I proceeded likewise by sawing away what appeared corrupted.
Deinde conatus sum restaurationem eius.	Thereafter I set about healing that wound as well, seeking restoration of its integrity and strength for a robust recovery
Et non est restauratum.	No, it is not yet restored or fully mended to healthy condition
Detexi ergo super ipsum iterum, et non cessaui incidere os particulatim, et conari restaurationem eius: et non est restauratum, donec incidi ex osse circiter palmum unum, et extraxi illud cum medulla sua.	Therefore I removed the bone repeatedly and continued not to cease cutting it in pieces; likewise attempting restoration of that particular part but without success – until having cut through the bone around its circumference about once a palm'th (approximately one handbreadth) - and extracting what remained with marrow.
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Thereafter I restored it with medicines and it was indeed properly consolidated – soundly fixed, healthily healed - without necessity for this repetition as part of its treatment; except that due to the weakness in his constitution which tolerates fewer sessions (and sections) because of fear on my part regarding death: For he suffered greatly from spasms and palpitations throughout all hours – caused by excessive release into the bloodstream, a sort of pulsation with harmful substances.
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	It is healing thusly as complete health; and it was born into a hard bone, and well-advised measures were taken for its body, and courageously went back to the ways of life: and conversed with itself about these matters.
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	If then the bone protruding into the body is already fractured: at that time it should be healed in this manner:" and thus, as follows:-it takes its own cartilages; a sinew being put therein to join ends of extremities joined together by their surface-and commands another tendon (or ligament), which spreads out the bone endward: let him place that other thicker band made from wool be first applied as ligature.
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Thereafter it is bound over the bone that has become a part of the flesh:" and let you extend its extremity so as to pull down towards the body's interior: place upon this point where cut into meat shall not harm.
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Put wood or a tablet under the bone below:" and that when you do it will not be forbidden for fear of rotting meat.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	It is necessary that the knife should be put over this place rotten to little degree:" and there shall not appear concavity of bone: nor shalt thou perceive it in its own sight; but let him encourage himself with another instrument, if need arise.
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	Whatsoever the bone is rotten and not emergent:" it continues to be a continuing piece with its own parts;" wherefore then corruption lies within or in any of those pieces; at that time take away all flesh from every particle.
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Thereafter, put down the wood below.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Thereafter cut this bone with the knife where it is rotten; until when you come to another part:" and let your cutting continue in that other part also;" so that together they shall be more than halfway through: as we have said.
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	If there is a rupture in the joint, make an incision into that joint and cut away the bone where it continues on one side.
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	If there is a rupture in the connection of two joints, then it is not within them but merely scraping.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	If there is a rupture in the tendon of the foot or hand, then it is difficult to heal within that area.
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	Therefore one must investigate how your injury appears.

Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem. Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And you know that these operations require special instruments for your particular case when assisting requires a prolonged study.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem. Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When an apostome occurs in some carnal members and the space of which is extended; until a saline collection has been formed: afterwards it either rises or breaks through with what lies within that particular member into a clean empty place as if there were nothing but air at such location, leaving behind skin covering over this area like recently removed clothing (bias) had previously adhered to the affected part; and does not reach its end in corruption of itself without first imprinting decay upon something else that is connected with these members until then it shall be called Sinus: but if the space continues, such lesion will be termed Fistula or alternatively. But when extended beyond a certain length on this particular member which has been damaged and infection spreads to other tissues of the body because there are no longer boundaries between them that can prevent contagious diseases from progressing throughout the body, then it is considered an abscess (fistula) until its decay invades some part connected with these members. If only a small area has been affected but still maintains distinct borders and does not spread to other tissues such as bone or muscle so that they remain unaffected: this isolated lesion, if it is in the groin region where there are no known boundaries between abdominal organs (viscera) for example - remains unchanged after being cut open. If only a small area of skin has been affected and still maintains distinct borders but extends beyond that particular member such as an arm or leg then this lesion becomes encapsulated, forming what may be called a fistula if its length exceeds 2 cm (1 inch), otherwise it is referred to simply by name. If the space continues after initial treatment and there are signs of further decay spreading from within: that area shall no longer be termed Sinus but instead Fistula, or alternatively Zucker
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And the treatment of his wound is to bind it all around just as he cut it out: and especially when it has been deeply penetrated like tissue paper, done so that it appears like cloth; also trusting because I have not left any part unattended due to decay.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	If you hope that the wound will heal itself and not lead to further decay as a consequence of it; and if there is congestion within the flesh due to meat, then care must be taken with Collyrium along with attention given to the chest area.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	If it is large and when it emits pus which has an unpleasant smell; then apply a Cleansing Soap along with Egyptian medicine that consists of vinegar, oil, and honey, by parts taken equally in water: and decoct over the fire until reddened medicaments are obtained. Then let them mix into sweet syrup to achieve thickness.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Thereafter take from it what you need; and dissolve the remainder with water and honey, Cleansing Soap of your wound Sinus: then tie off its opening, and remove the medicine at two-hour intervals.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Thereafter apply it externally with a poultice for the day until your Wound sinuses are cleaned and odors have been removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And when you are cleansed with soot water and not presently in possession of this medicament; then take charcoal ash from the stove or heated ivy leaves, sprinkle it over your wound site: and let flow warm liquid above it to cover completely.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Thereafter apply honey onto the poultice made from charcoal ash and wash your Wound sinuses clean until they are rinsed away; then trust that it is now cleansed.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	If you find that even when ill the patient is not tolerant of Egyptian medicine and neither soot water nor Cleansing Soap: then apply a Clister to your Wound Sinus with warm water mixed with honey, wherein has been added something from my concoction made out of Ziniar. The poultice should be firmly pressed on until fully absorbed.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Then wash the wound internally with honey and wine mixed together; for of the nature of honey it is that which purifies but also cleanses away, making adhesion to the belly especially when there are excess fluids and dryness within.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	Whenever you perform that a few times and reveal what the distended belly now is, then internally wash with honey whatever makes flesh grow within.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And it is that you receive from the bedside some sweet-smelling oil or wine as healing: and dissolve with rosewater; or internally wash with certain medicines and ointments of which I have described their properties, in my treatise on unguents.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	But if the distended belly has an opening where not even to insert clotted honey: then you should enlarge it with as much iron as possible; or place inside of that narrowed outlet in Egyptian unguent, or Basilincun extract until it is expanded.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And similarly if there is an enlarged opening as well; then you should pull together the lips of that and sew them shut with a thread.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And similarly if there is an opening from which flows out bloodstained discharge that runs down to the surface above; then you should dry it inside wherein lies its excretion until running backward into below: because when such pus gets constricted within, prohibits further generation of flesh in.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	But if it is not possible for you to dry the lower part of that belly about its circumference in a way as has been taught you: then take along with thee, such substances which are caused by running pus out together so easily prepared according to your custom.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	But take along with thee nothing remaining of that discharge from the belly; and receive ready-made drugs which are placed over signs caused by bloodstained pus so in keeping with what flows out.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And extend it above with a thread.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	Let the amount of cloth be such that there is communication between all parts of the spleen.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then insert fingers into the mouth opening directly to the narrow sinus passage. More than usual (amplius).
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then extend the cloth with oil wetted fingers over a different part of the other fabric according to the size of the sinuses (openings): and place it in such position beyond the mouth opening from which saliva would come out: do not remove the cloth unless after several days of one drops.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	He who is above the sinus opening is he whom one rubs in every hour so that it can grow out of what accumulates there (pus): and know this also, whether that which runs from him are little worms or not: they may be few, as much as a part; some more, others less.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	Repeat this process with regard to the same sinus place: and whether there is pain or not (in him), it may be that he does not feel any pain; rather than being numb inside, or even more so feeling an intense pressure from within as if pushed out. Or alternatively again they do not experience such sensation either way of suffering nor relief.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	So when you tend to medicine like this and see the substance that has entered through his sinus opening (hole), then know whether it adheres inside or nearly so: thusly take care of himself in bed for a day at least, or even more preferably on the third day; once up again unroll one cloth and rub oil over another.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	If he then comes out through the sinus opening after a long time worm (he is infected with tinea), do not despair of adherence to him: for his recovery approaches quickly because there are some people among men who take their generation into consideration, and others whose nature opposes contrary things.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	If after a few days an abscess has burst out from the Sinus, then you know that the sinus did not adhere.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	If then the adherence of the Sinus is delayed and prolonged, do so include it also in medical treatment; let physicians make medicines from their own humid substances and dry ones such as to have healing salve added when there are superfluous exudations.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the greater last that is cured it follows to take healing salve (dyafinicon) and rub with rose oil, and remove on its old wound dressing made of equal parts substance: let them be dissolved when needed into their own humid medicines.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Thereafter secure the healed area with it and use as directed.

¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	On the use of phlebotomy and cautioning in observation thereof.
