Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And so that bloodletting can be performed on the first or third day after having observed for three hours beyond daily intervals of time (post quam praeterierint).
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	However, the time for which bloodletting is administered when there are diseases has not a fixed hour: but whenever it seems convenient and necessary to do so - at night or daytime as well throughout every moment of each day over all seasons.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not fitting that the bloodletting should be performed on children until they have passed four decades of age.

Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Not even old men who are already past sixty years of age should be subjected to bloodletting.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	Therefore when someone wishes to undergo bloodletting for any reason, it is necessary that the patient purifies his bowels beforehand with a laxative if there remains much feces in them: so as not to expose the main members of the body harmfully due to putrid excrements coming from excessive evacuations.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Nor should the patient suffer hunger or intoxication leading to indigestion while undergoing bloodletting.

And the bloodletting is repeated after a bout of colic pain related to menstrual periods, and in women and fluid discharge, sexual intercourse, childbirth labor, physical exercise, gladiatorial contests, slave chariot driving, fasting days dedicated to Corpus Christi or other religious practices that dissolve bodily strength.

The mention of "rubedo sanguinis" indicates a turning red of blood that may be interpreted as both an indicator of heat and inflammation or possibly the symbolic completion of certain stages in this treatment process, leading to physical mark

¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What is it that must be done with the oil at positions of the Wind Stealers and what should we avoid to prevent ulceration?

Indeed to that person whose skin is hard, thick, blackened and has tight pores, we must anoint the areas of the Wind Stealers with open oil containers; heating, easing outcomes are required: if in summer time, like olive oil from Aleppo or strong wine vinegar. And if it is a windy day for the chest or pleura (the lung), tender breast meat; then we must take care that they are anointed with oil so as not to catch fire, and let those spots affected by the Wind be washed after exposure either with rose water warmly poured over them, cold rose water, hot sour water or aqueous of Cucumber (cucumber juice) or Portulaca (purslane). And similar things to them.

And similar things.

Oportet, ut dicamus in prologo huius Capituli, summas sermonis, et capitula, ad quarum intellectum cogitur in primis artifex ad stationem super earum ueritatem: scilicet ut uos, et qui sunt prompti, sciant, uel addiscant hanc artem nobilem, et alii a uobis.	Let us begin in the prologue of this book with our chief sermon and its chapters; firstly, let it be that we consider carefully those master craftsmen who specialize soledearing excellence at repairing ears: namely so taught to their immediate audience both by word and deed.
Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	I say that when an injury such as a fracture or dislocation occurs; then it is necessary to first treat the bleeding by phlebotomy and afterwards remove whatever there may be within: provided nothing prohibits this, like weakness of morals if he suffers from vices associated with youthful folly, those who are elderly deteriorating in health or when one experiences sudden heat due to feverish conditions.

Once you are securely seated on a hot bench and not for extended periods, then return the weakened person to their usual routine of health with first things as per their habitual customs: where they used to sit comfortably before becoming ill.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	So that when the fracture begins to be repaired; it is necessary at that time for a weakened patient's food to contain plenty of fatty and coarse substances as well, like bread made from wheat cooked with water or rice, barley cakes (grapia), cabbage leaves, lentils, boar feet, gooseberries, beer wort, oats, pears, fishes freshly caught. And wine that is thick and similar to these foods as well: all of which are considered part of a fracture patient's diet during recovery according to the textbook from Albucasis on surgery in Arabic writing translated into Latin by Archbishop Hugo von Trentinensis around 1025. The original source is likely attributed to Albucasis himself (Al-Bīshārī, Ibn) as he was a renowned medieval Muslim physician and surgeon known for his detailed surgical texts which have significantly influenced the field of medicine in Europe through various translations during the Middle Aged Latin period.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	When this method is followed, healing occurs faster in bone fractures.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	And you know that bones fractured in old men who are senile and decrepit cannot maintain or heal themselves naturally at all times due to the contraction of their muscles: they become compacted like children'selfs baby teeth, as well as becoming continuous with them.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	However, nature adheres to the fractured bone from all sides with something similar to gluten, which gives it thickness and firmly holds itself together until they are united in one substance as a result of inflammation caused by injury: this is why we must place food for sick people on dishes containing such ingredients; because therein lies their heaviness and viscosity.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	And you know that bone fractures are different, according to the nature of muscles and other parts; because a knee joint fracture is very much unlike a fractured neck bone: and a fractured breastbone is quite dissimilar from a backbone fracture; just as all remaining body members have differences among them. And I come now with my exposition of each type of fracture discussed in this chapter, distinctly set apart from other types.
Et diuersificantur species fracturae ossis etiam in seipsa.	Fractures are also diverse within themselves.
Quoniam fit fractura eius arcuata, praeter quod accidant in ea astellae.	Because this type of fracture is curved beyond the fact that it occurs on seaweed-covered rocks.
Et quandoque fit fractura eius secundum longitudinem ossis: et sunt fracturae eius satagiae, id est, astellae, et additiones procedentes, sicut sunt in calamo, cum aptatur cultello ad scribendum.	And when this type of fracture happens according to the length of the bone; it is called a spongy or seaweed-like fracture due to its resemblance to pieces and additions on papyrus, as fit for writing in with a reed pen.
Et non procedentes: et est fractura cum uulnere et disruptione in capite: et est fractura fissura parua.	And it does not proceed with a wound and is a fracture or partial dislocation of the head, which is a partial fracture.
Et omni speciei est ingenium, uel instrumentum proprium in restauratione eius, secundum quod ueniet rememoratio eius, distincta in locis suis.	And it concerns every species of skill or device particular to its restoration, as recalled from that place within those same places.
Et ex eo quo cognoscitur fractura ossis, est tortuositas eius, et ipsius eminentia: et apparitio eius sensui, et sonitus eius quando comprimis ipsum manu tua.	And from what is known of a bone'thrust fracture, it has its twists and prominence thereof; the appearance of that contusion to sense and sound when compressed by your hand upon it.)
Quando ergo non est in loco tortuositas apparens, neque sonitus apud tactum tuum cum tangis os cum agitatione, neque inuenit infirmus magnum dolorem: tunc non est illic fractura, imo possibile est, ut sit tortuositas, aut fissura parua: non ergo oportet, ut moueas ipsum cum manu et compressione omnino, imo pone super ipsum ex medicinis, quarum uenit rememoratio, post momentum illud quod conuenit loco: deinde stringatur strictura subtili.	When I then am not in the place of apparent twists or when there is no sound with your touch upon it while turning its bone with agitation; nor does a great weakness come, which pain accompanies after such an injury: thus perhaps this fracture may be something other than just one possessing twists and being partially separated (that's to say partial dislocation), or maybe simply the prominence of these contusions on their own. Therefore it is not appropriate that you should move his wrist with hand touches at all times, especially under this new force which comes after such a movement; thereafter strictness follows in subtlety.)
Et scias, quod locus quando arcuatur, et scinditur in duo, praeter quod accidant in eo satagiae, uerumtamen remouetur omnis pars a compari sua: tunc oportet tibi, ut incipias ab hora tua ad rectificationem eius, aequando ipsum antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And you know that the place where an arch is and it splits into two; even if they fall therein, yet all parts are brought back to compare with its own: therefore it behooves thee, as soon at thine hour begin thy rectification of him upon this painful chill.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum, tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec quiescat apoestema.	And if the wound then becomes feverish (burning), let it rest for a few days until there is no more burning pain. It may need to be discharged on specific conditions.)
Deinde aequa ipsum secundum quemcunque modum potest ex lenitate et ingenio.	Thereafter, bring the injured part as gently and skillfully as possible in any manner that can make it so (i.e., healing).)
Et scias, quod restauratio eius, et ipsius aequatio, est facilior quam ossis, in quo accidunt satagiae.	And you know that the restoration of him and his alleviation is easier than bone which has such blows (that's to say fractures).)
Deinde stringe ipsum, secundum quod ueniet tibi rememoratio eius.	Then proceed to do it in accordance with what has come into your memory about that matter.
Si uero in osse sunt satagiae, tunc necessaria est extensio huius membri fracti ex duabus partibus, si manus sit, aut pes: aut cum manu tua, si membrum est paruum: aut cum duobus funibus, aut cum fune et manu.	If there are splinters in the bone, then it is necessary to make this member broken by two parts, if of hand or foot; with your finger on a round part, or between fingers and thumb: or using two ropes, or thread, together with the needle.
Et sit positio tua qua ponis membrum super locum aequalem, secundum figuram suam naturalem, donec quando extenduntur partes membri fracti: tunc conare, ut redire facias illas additiones omni ingenio, et secundum quemcunque modum potes in locis suis: et caue secundum fortitudinem tuam, ne accidat super infirmum per operationem tuam dolor, neque laesio: et conare secundum fortitudinem tuam, ut applices unum duorum ossium cum socio suo, secundum meliores formas. Apply carefully also, so as your arm or leg is applied to the corresponding part of a bone; taking care which better forms you choose for yourself according to whatever position and manner suits at those places: be courageous that strength does not fall upon an infirm person through operation on him painfully by force. Be cautious also, in applying your arm or leg with two pieces of flesh (so as they may conform more naturally) correspondingly together after the fracture has been reduced to its proper position; so according then at that time you apply carefully: and be courageous therein likewise through strength for better results.

Si ergo uides illic aliquid diuersum, rectifica ipsum, et aequa illud per quantitatem tuae uirtutis.	If therefore you see something different thereafter for some time; correct that thing and make it straight once more by the strength of your virtues.
Et caue extensionem uehementem, et compressionem fortem, sicut faciunt multi stolidorum.	And take hold with great force upon its stretching to compress; which they do as if done unto stone.

Often for this reason have I seen such as happened by their own operations cold or constriction on part of the limb; which now learn from those things that happen in others’ affairs, and may take heed lest any similar thing should ever befal them themselves through negligence.

Take roots of old altheas and flax seeds, balsam stones (balusta), honeycomb pieces with nectar, samsum leaves, flower of yarrows, chamomile flowers all together in one part; mix them well with water from willow or meadowsweet trees, or plain sweet water, to make a concoction: This elaborate medieval recipe once again shows the reliance on natural ingredients for healing. The use of 'water salicis' (willow bark) and its medicinal properties reflects an early understanding of what we now know as aspirin’s pain-relieving qualities, predating modern medicine by centuries. Totum illud secundum caliditatem membri, et quietem caloris eius.	According to its temperature and exposure to heat.
Hippocrates uero non dixit in libro suo, quod ponatur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius, nisi caerotum factum ex caera, et oleo: non aliud: et narrauit, ut sit medium inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem.	Hippocrates indeed said in his book that one should apply heat to a fractured limb only if the bone is broken and there's oil (olive), but nothing else: he wrote about something as an intermediate between magnitude and subtlety.
Galeno autem uisum est, ut ponantur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius res, in quibus est exiccatio caliditatis, sicut myrrha, et aloes et olibanum, et similia eis ex eis quae narrauimus.	Galen also said that they should place the fractured limb in restorations according to it, where there is an evaporation of heat as myrrh, and aloes and cinnammon; these are things we mentioned earlier on this page (if a translation refers back without further context).
¶ Modus Emplastri quod confert ad laesionem et dolorem.	The emplastic mode which affords injury and pain.
Recipe mugath, et ciceris, et capillorum hominis incisorum, aut pennae auis, et alteae, et salis partes aequales: terantur, et cribellentur, et conficiantur: et fiat ex eo emplastrum.	Take equal parts of mugwort, chickpeas, and the hairs from man's lips or quills/feathers as well as other things mentioned earlier on this page (if a translation refers back without further context). They should be ground together with salt: they will turn into an ointment. Let it come out of that mixture paste-like substance, emplastrum.
Quantitas autem secundum quam oportet, ut remaneat ligatura, deinde soluatur, est, ut consideres tunc, si non accidit infirmo dolor, neque pruritus, neque mouetur os fractum a loco suo: tunc non resoluas ipsum diebus multis.	The quantity must be such that the band remains as needed; then it is to be dissolved (loosened), and considered now if not afflicted with pain, nor pricking sensation of the fractured limb away from its original place: at this time you should leave the matter unresolved for several days.
Quod si accidat ei in loco pruritus uehemens, aut dolor inquietans, aut inflatio: tunc propera, et solue in hora ipsum, et aufer emplastrum ab eo: et accipe pannum lenem, aut spongiam marinam lenem, humidam: et submerge eam in aqua tepida, et ablue cum ea locum, donec quiescat pruritus, et sedetur dolor.	If pain or unease occurs at that spot constantly (chronically): then the proper treatment is given right away; and remove it on its time-hour: moreover let no band remain from this ointment for you to apply externally afterward in your bathing hour, but take instead a soft linen cloth or sea sponge soaked with warm water, moistened: then immerse that into the hot water at the same temperature as it was before (if I say aqua tepida), and drain off together with its spot until there remains no more pruritus but only pain which sits still.
Deinde dimitte membrum quiescere una hora.	Afterwards release a limb for one hour.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam succidam, submersam in aceto et oleo, aut oleo rosato: et liga super ipsum nocte una, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido, et quiescat inflatio membri, et remoueatur dolor eius.	Thereafter place a wound dressing on the skin with vinegar or olive oil (or rose-colored oil), and secure it overnight; until he is sure of removing the hot aspheteric bandage safely, let inflammation subside in the limb, then remove pain.
Deinde itera ipsum ad stricturam subtilem, et emplastrum paruum: et non stringas ipsum constrictione tua prima, et subtilia cum eo, donec sanetur.	Thereafter apply the same repeatedly to a fine-textured substance and pounded wound plaster; but do not bind your first restraint firmly on it, and with its fineness carefully cover until healed securely.]
Quod si uides, quod apostema, et rubedo, et dolor, et inflatio, et omnia accidentia iam remota sunt penitus, et indiges emplastro et strictura, tunc itera illud sicut fecisti in primis aequaliter.	Which if you see that the aspheteric condition and redness, pain, inflammation, and all other accidents are now entirely cured abroad, then remove purging plaster (i.f.) and restraint at once.]
Quod si non accidit membro aliquid ex eis quae diximus, tune non soluas ipsum, nisi post tres dies, aut quatuor, aut quinque, aut septem.	Which if the limb does not experience anything from what we have mentioned then it is healed; but should there be a continued complaint after three days or four, five, seven of them.]
Et quando que dimittitur uiginti diebus totum illud, secundum quod apparet tibi ex solutione membri, sicut diximus, donec quando adhaeret fractura, et approximat coagulatio carnis super eam: adde etiam tunc in strictura plus quam strictura tua prima tota: et adde etiam in ingrossatione cibi infirmi, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius.	And when that healing time has gone on for nine days total (as it appears from the condition of your limb), as we said before; but if a fracture still adheres to and an approximation in coagulation over this remains, then add more than just the first restraint plus all: also at mealtime feed foods that are heavy. And remember no longer.]
Si autem uides locum fracturae iam exiccari, et extenuari plus quam oportet: tunc scias, quod nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad ipsum.	But if you see that there is a place where the bone has broken out already; and when it becomes more inflamed than ought to be (if not properly bandaged), then know this: at once cease eating for food with such matter, as we said before.]
Embroca ergo ipsum cum aqua tepida apud omnem uicem qua soluis ipsum, et sit illud in omnibus tribus diebus, et alleuia stricturam parumper.	Therefore immerse the wound as well with warm water at every place where you have set it on any stone exposed to sunlight: let that be done continuously for three days and a half (a fortnight), always keeping tight pressure plasters barely open.]
Per hanc ergo operationem currit ad membrum nutrimentum, et sanatur uelociter.	This operation leads to nourishment flowing towards the limb and it is healed properly.
Illud autem quod faciunt stolidi restauratores ex fractura membri uice alia, quando non restauratur in primis, secundum quod oportet, et restauratur secundum tortuositatem, est error ex operatione eorum, et timor magnus: et si esset rectum, dixissent illud antiqui in libris suis, et operati fuissent cum eo.	That which they perform those ignorant restorers for the fracture of a limb when not first restored and then according to twist is wrong from that operation; there arises great fear: but if it were straight (correct), these ancient people would say so in their books, and do such operations accordingly.
Et ego non uidi alicubi eorum uestigium in illo omnino, et rectius est, ut non fiat illud.	And I myself have not seen any part of that investigation by them into this at all; it is rightly straight (correct).

¶ De restauratione Anchae.	On restoring an anchor.
Caput XI.	Chapter Eleven.
Raro franguntur ossa Ancharum.	Uncommonly do bones of anchors break.
Quod si franguntur, tunc fractura eorum non est, nisi comminutio in extremitatibus ipsorum: et scinduntur in longitudine, et declinantur ad interiora: et accidit infirmo dolor in loco, et punctura: et stupescit crus quod frangitur.	But if they break, then the bones are not fractured except for a comminution at their extremities; and they split along length, and fall away towards the interior parts of them: it happens that there is pain in that place with an entry point or puncture wound, and numbness falls upon that which has broken.

That if the bone is broken only at its extremities, then such a break will be made to correspond with one's natural figure as prepared by equation until it becomes similar in shape.
Si autem fractura est in longitudine, aut iam declinat ad interiora: tunc fac iacere infirmum super uentrem suum, donec praeparetur tibi restauratio illius fracturae.	If the bone is broken lengthwise or inclines towards the inside: then I must make an intervention on its extremity and continue until such repair of that person' endured their fracture has been prepared for restoration.

When then you have made it equal, put an overlay on that very thing itself and afterwards place a splint over the same from wood or skin: but attach firmly without allowing any shifting of either pieces nor removal of said splints during healing until your repair has been sufficiently prepared for recovery.
Et aequa concauitatem illorum cum eo quod impleat eam, donec capiat eam strictura secundum aequalitatem: et praecipe infirmo, ut dormiat super dorsum suum, aut super latus suum sanum.	And if you find that they agree with this treatment as it is carried out, keep applying until the fracture has been closed according to equality: and command them so ill-adjusted (in pain) not to sleep on their back but rather on either side of their body in comfort.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc cessa ab extensione eius, et ipsius restauratione, donec sedetur apostema calidum: et pone super ipsum quod sedet ipsum, secundum quod praecessit, deinde redi ad restaurationem eius: et stringe ipsum sicut oportet. And bind the fracture likewise in accordance with necessity.

And when the dislocation is towards anterior, then it must be that his weak leg extends more quickly and firmly as before; also he puts a hand on the injured man's right side below.
Deinde coartet ipsum cum manu altera, et cum illa coartatione pone ipsum extensum ad inferiora ad partem genu.	Then that is tightened with his other hand and when he gets the hind loin together it must be extended downwards to its corresponding place.
Et si dislocatio est ad posteriora: tunc non oportet, ut extendatur infirmus ad inferiora, et sit eleuatus super terram: imo oportet, ut sit positus super rem duram, sicut oportet, ut fit etiam si dislocatur ancha eius ad exteriora, secundum illud quod diximus de accubitu eius super duas anchas: et est super faciem eius, et ligamenta extensa: secundum quod diximus nuper.	If the dislocation is towards posterior, then it must not be that his weak leg extends downwards and he should lie on earth; rather, it ought to remain upright supported by firm things like a pillow over him as also we have described for those who are lying with two supports (planks) under their hips: the same thing happens when they are dislocated ankleward towards outside.
Et oportet, ut administretur compressio cum tabula etiam super locum ad quem egreditur iunctura, cum completur reductio secundum quod oportet.	It is necessary that it be applied compression with a sponge and also on the place to which one withdraws feeling as well as reduction according to what needs to happen.
Et signum reditionis eius non occultatur tibi: et est, ut extendas duo crura infirmi: et quando uides ea aequalia, et infirmus stringit crus suum, et expandit ipsum absque excusatione: tunc scias, quia iam redit membrum, secundum quod oportet: tunc coniunge duas coxas, et pone emplastrum, et stringe cum imemati, id est, rota: ita, ut non moueatur ancha ad aliquam partium: et adhaereat infirmus quieti tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	The sign of his return is not hidden from you: and here indeed he extends two arms to the sick: when you see that equality has been reached between them, so that the weak arm draws back its own leg, and stretches forth without excuse; at such a time will you know that the member has returned, following what needs to happen: then join together the two hips, and place on bandage, and bind with memory (i.e., using rope): in this way it shall not move abruptly towards some part of the body but adhere quietly for three or four days.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et emplastrum, et compara crus cum altero: tunc si uides ea aequalia in statu, tunc scias, quod dislocatio iam firmata est: absolue ergo infirmum ad ambulandum.	Thereafter proceed with the ligament and bandage, and apply skin to one leg; then if you see that equality has been restored in position, at such a time will you know that dislocation is now firmly fixed: hence release him free (i.e., allowing him to walk).
Et si uides aliquid mollificationis: tunc redi, et emplastra illud, et stringe illud secundum stricturam tuam primam: et dimitte illud etiam tribus diebus.	And if you see that softening has occurred: then return with the bandage and apply it again; bind this according to your first strength (i.e., firmly but not too tight): let go of such a thing also for three or four days.
Deinde solue illud et fac ipsum tardare in ambulatione super utrumque aliquot diebus, donec confortetur bene.	Thereafter proceed with the bandage and continue to delay walking over either side for as long as necessary until he is comfortably supported (i.e., not forced into movement too soon).

Et signum dislocationis eius est, quod uides Calcaneum inflatum, procedentem ad partem ad quam dislocatur.	And the sign of a dislocation is that you see blood coming out from where it has been displaced towards its separated part.

¶ De speciebus dislocationis cum uulnere uel fractura.	Concerning displaced bones with a wound, or when dealing with both a dislocation and a fracture. 
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter XXXVI. 
Quando accidit aliquid ex illo, et conaris curationem eius, et ipsius restaurationem, multotiens succedit mors: et propter illud non oportet, ut praesumat super curationem eius, quod est huiusmodi, nisi qui est prudens in arte longi usus, misericors, pius, tardus, non audax, neque praesumptuosus: et ut utatur in incaeptionce medicinis quae sedant apostemata calida tantum: et dimittat infirmum diuino iudicio.	When something happens to the patient from within, and applies for its own cure while still under treatment; such a course of action often leads death: therefore it should not be entrusted with overseeing this kind of medical care, which involves treating patients whose sole condition is having inflamed sores hot only by touch alone, until they recover. And let the feeble and weak patient in God's judgment rest for some time; one who has been trained long enough to use medicine prudently without fear or pity must be slow but cautious not greedy nor presumptuous about administering treatment which should not exceed their competence, especially when dealing with patients whose sole condition is having inflamed sores hot only by touch alone.
Nisi uideas, aut speras salutem a perditione cum lenitate aegritudinis, et in quo apparet quiddam spei.	If you do not understand or hope for health rather than facing punishment and suffering together with easiness of illness; then it becomes apparent something about which one hopes. 
Conare ergo reductionem eius statim in principio rei, antequam accidat apostema calidum.	Therefore begin the reduction immediately at first sight before suffering from an inflamed sore warm to touch. 
Si ergo redit membrum, secundum quod uolumus, tunc administra regimen quod sedat apostema: et cura uulnus cum eo quod conuenit ei ex unguentis desiccatiuis.	If therefore the limb returns as we wish it to do; then immediately apply a treatment that soothes inflamed sores, and care for him with medicines made from dried secretions according to his preference at that time. 
Quod si dislocatio est cum fractura, et accidunt in osse satagiae separatae, tunc conare ablationem earum, et fac in illo quod diximus in aegritudinibus simplicibus ex eo quod praecessit in locis earum.	If therefore dislocation is with fracture and the bones have separated inside; then immediately remove them (the broken pieces), after which to do as we said above regarding patients who suffer from simple illnesses, using remedies that came out of those places where they had previously existed. This suggests immediate surgical intervention followed by specific treatments for recovery without complications similar to mild cases. 
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, et custodi teipsum ab introitu in uiam timoris: secundum quod praecessit praedicatio mea tibi.	And let your strength guide you; and take care to avoid the fear of entering water which has escaped from my prediction for you, as I have said that it would happen according to what was fated in prophecy. Nam illud est melius tibi apud Creatorem tuum, et magis permanens ad gloriam tuam, et magis saluum tuo corpori apud illos in tuo tempore.	That is better for you by your Lord and God, and more abiding with Him forevermore, and more preserving of thy body among them at that time.
